thread.title: White House opens 2nd appeal of order halting Trump travel ban
thread.title_full: White House opens 2nd appeal of order halting Trump travel ban

author: ADAM EDELMAN
title: White House opens 2nd appeal of order halting Trump travel ban
text:
White House begins formal appeal of 9th Circuit Court ruling that upheld illegality of Trump’s travel and refugee ban White House opens 2nd appeal of order halting Trump travel ban NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated:  14 PM 
The White House filed papers Monday to formally appeal last week’s federal court ruling that upheld a suspension of President Trump’s travel ban. 
The motion, which indicates the administration is likely to seek an appeal before a panel larger than the three-judge 9th Circuit Court of Appeals, marks the first formal legal response by the Trump administration to a Feb. 9 ruling by the San Francisco-based court, which upheld an earlier District Court ruling. That action prevented the federal government from barring travelers from seven Muslim-majority nations and suspending, then limiting, the nation’s refugee program. 
Trump himself had threatened to pursue the case through the Supreme Court, but Monday’s motion indicates the White House will hold off on that approach — for now. 
The motion confirms one of the multiple scenarios that Stephen Miller, a senior policy adviser to Trump, said the White House was considering to keep the measure alive. 
President Trump calls most recent court setback 'disgraceful' 
Those options, Miller said Sunday, included seeking an emergency stay at the Supreme Court, continuing the appeal with the panel, requesting an emergency hearing before the full circuit and “going to the trial court at the district level and trial on the merit.” 
They also included “the possibility of new executive actions designed to prevent terrorist infiltration of our country,” Miller said during a blitz of appearances on political talk shows Sunday morning. Protesters rally in NYC against Trump's travel ban 
Miller reiterated the administration’s belief that Trump can do whatever he wants — simply because he is the President. 
“We have a judiciary that has taken far too much power and become in many cases a supreme branch of government,” Miller said on CBS’ “Face the Nation.” 
White House looking at all options to keep Trump travel ban alive 
“Our opponents, the media, and the whole world will soon see, as we begin to take further actions, that the power of the President to protect our country are very substantial and will not be questioned.” 
“The President’s powers here are beyond question,” he added — directly contradicting the San Francisco court’s ruling. 
The California panel of three judges, reviewing a decision by a federal judge in Seattle that blocked parts of the order, noted in its ruling that the states raised serious allegations about religious discrimination and, in plain language, rejected the Trump administration’s argument that his executive orders are “unreviewable.” President Trump had suggested several possible responses to the federal appeals court ruling upholding an injunction on his travel and refugee ban. The White House on Monday began its first formal response. (NICHOLAS KAMM/AFP/Getty Images) 
“There is no precedent to support this claimed unreviewability, which runs contrary to the fundamental structure of our constitutional democracy,” the judges wrote. 
Brooklyn chef discusses why he supports immigrants over Trump 
The judges also found merit to the states’ argument that the ban, barring travelers from seven Muslim-majority nations and limiting the nation’s refugee program, violates the Fifth Amendment right to due process, contending that the executive branch will have little “likelihood of success” in rejecting that argument. 
“The government has not shown that the executive order provides what due process requires, such as notice and a hearing prior to restricting an individual’s ability to travel,” the panel wrote. 
The 29-page ruling appeared to rule out several of Miller’s suggestions Sunday, saying it was unlikely the White House counsel had authority to amend a presidential executive order and that the government did not show how the order could be administered in parts. Tags:
